Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Comment: Bakasa = to hunt. At 14:14 he gives a speech in Tetun Terik to warn hunting participants to listen to each other, not swear, so that we will get what we want.

Feature: Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: See answer to 7 for an example.

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: Everyone understands the language used in ceremonies and traditional stories. Eik nanoik = traditional stories.

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Are there ritual dances?
Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Do women and men dance together?
Comment: Men and women can dance a lego-lego in a mixed fashion, with man-woman-man-woman etc.

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: In the rumah adat, men and women must meet separately.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: This answer is given around question 10.3, where he explains about the ritual and the language used.The ritual takes place every year before the harvest and involves cutting up a  goat or a pig and the meat is lifted up, and a prayer is said to the sacred objects in the rumah adat and the ancestors (around 01:07; another one at 01:30, with free translation in Indonesian.)

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: the rumah adat but also the land where crops are planted

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: Rice wine, sirih pinang

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: The rumah adat.

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: After the baby is born, the umbilical cord and placenta are put on the top of a tree. There is a ritual called fasi matang 'wash eyes', takes place a week after a baby is born. It does not involve washing anything, but rather cutting off some of the baby's hair. The parents and family express various types of good wishes to the child.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: A body is buried after 3 days, covered in traditional woven cloth. After the burial, food and drink is put at the grave for 40 days.

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: Before planting, the land is cermoniously sprinkled with coconut milk to make it fertile.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Comment: Tetun Terik woven cloth from Viqueque are special, they have their own colours and patterns.

Feature: Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: baba = small drum held at shoulder (Tetun D liku rai); korneta = flute, tambor = drum

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: The question is understood to be about brushing teeth.

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Comment: In the past, it was normal to not cut a boy's hair until he is grown up. The cutting took place when he was an adult, and was part of a ritual. The hair was put below a banana tree.

Feature: Traditional piercings?
Comment: In the past, men had ear piercings. Today, this is also a modern style.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: Head piece for women made from male chicken feathers and plaited leaves: man fulung. Men do not have any leg adornments in Viqueque.

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: Fita lima = bracelet for men made of copper (?), kai bouk = head piece for men, morteng = necklace for women.Gold or silver is not used.

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: See 13.4 and 13.5

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Comment: Loro mosu = East (sun go.up); loro tung (sun go.down) = West; tasi feto (sea female)= Northern sea, tasi mane (sea male) = Southern sea. Because the waves in the northern sea are less wild than  those of the southern sea of Timor. Fulang loro = moon sun;  ina fulang, ama loro = mother moon, father sun; kuana = right, karuk = left.

Feature: Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Tetun Terik speakers also speak Makasae and Naueti, Makasae speakers also speak Tetun Terik and Naueti in Viqueque.

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: When children are still small, they speak only Tetun Terik. But when they grow up to become adults they also learn Makasae and Naueti.

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: When the spouse comes from somewhere outside Viqueque, they speak Tetun Dili.But it is better if the spouse learns to speak Tetun Terik, because many people in Viqueque do not speak Tetun Dili very well.When the spouse is from Viqueque they both speak Tetun Terik.

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: When the wife comes from outside, she would learn Tetun Terik or else she would have difficulties communicating with her family and neighbours in Viqueque.

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: If necessary they use a third language but over time, the wife who does not speak Tetun Terik will learn her husband's language.

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: yes,10% or less   Bakasa = to hunt. Wild pigs, deer.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: The sea is too far from Viqueque.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: yes, 70-80% of the people have cattle    goats, pigs, chicken, water buffalo, horses, dogs, cows ('sapi Bali'); everyone has chicken and pig but not everyone has goats, cows and buffalos

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: Mostly dry gardens, there are also wet rice fields which are irrigated. The gardens are ~10 km from the house, the rice fields are closer.

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Comment: Gardens are left for a year because otherwise the soil is not fertile enough

Feature: Major crops?
Comment: coconuts, rice, corn, green beans, candle nut, sugar cane, cassava, potato

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: The  notion 'suku' or 'clan' is unclear. The question is interpreted as: are there 'rumah adat'. This seems to be a moiety rather than a clan.

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: In Viqueque there are the following 'rumah adat' (some examples): Betuk Hun (betuk=k.o.big.bamboo, hun=tree), Kai Boki, Jan Bua Mahan, Balidi Mahan, Manu Uen (mahan=shade, balidi = buah asing, manu=chicken, uen = liquid, melt). The speaker belongs to Betuk Hun. This group comprises about 40 people. These 5 rumah adat are mutually connected. In the past, they could intermarry, but nowadays this is forbidden by the church because the family connections are too close.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: Each of the five groups mentioned above has its own rumah adat.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: Yes, the Betuk Hun, Kai Boki and Jan Bua Mahan have kings, but the Balidi Mahan and Manu Uen do not.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Comment: There are dialectal differences but they are geographically determined, not following clan lines.

Feature: Is real property (land) inherited?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: A king did not own all the land. In the Portuguese times, kings did have the privilige that only their children could go to school. Groups with kings are Betuk Hun, Kai Boki and Jan Bua Mahan, the other two groups are not kings. Later, as a response to question 8.5, a royal family named Uhacae is mentioned (in Viqueque, desa Umain Kraik), and it is said that they own all the land.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Are there inheritance rules?
Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Comment: Only sons inherit.

Feature: Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Comment: Only sons inherit.

Feature: Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: The eldest son is the heir, if he has one or more brothers, these may get some of the heirloom, depending on what the parents decide, but most of it (at least 75%) goes to the eldest son.

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: A newcomer can buy land. When he dies, his heirs keep the ownership because they have a written contract. For example, Chinese. But there are very few foreigners that buy land. Javanese rent land.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: In former times, men should marry at about 30, women at about 20     Nowadays there are no age restrictions, girls can get married at 15, boys at 17-19. The explanation for the earlier age restrictions is that boys and girls should first become adults before they get married. Later marriage is not related to organizing a bride price.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: yes, in earlier days there were rules but not anymore            In former times, cousins could get married, but this is no longer allowed by the church. The first step in a marriage is when the two parties meet to negotiate. This is called: kasu lia 'let go/loose voice' = to inform.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: Food and drinks are exchanged as a public sign that the couple is married. Food may be rice, drinks may be water or palm wine.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: Before they get married, the bride price must be there. If there is not enough yet then he will not ask for the woman.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: They belong to the husband's kin group but can stay somewhere else for work, e.g. live in Dili.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
Comment: Formerly, this was not obligatory, but nowadays it is.

Feature: If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: The children remain with the father, even if he remarries.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Comment: It still happens, e.g. when a wife cannot have children, or had children who died, then the man can get a second wife. The two women live in the same house with the man.

Feature: Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: Makasae and Fataluku women are expensive, Tetun Terik women are less expensive. The bried price consists of money, buffalo, horses, woven cloth, necklace, earrings. The term for bride price is fo feto foling lit. 'give woman price'.

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: Only pigs, to be eaten by the family at the wedding. No clothes or other objects are given by the bride's side.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: Some families may temporarily live away from the village, to e.g. guard the gardens, or work in the gardens. But these are temporary settlements. (It is mentioned that the Naueti place where the president of Timor Leste comes from, does have such dispersed family homesteads, because each family must stay on its own land.)

Feature: Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Comment: Villages usually have more than 2000 inhabitants.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: This is found in e.g. the Betu Hun group.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Comment: For Tetun people that live in the mountains.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Comment: For Tetun people that live near the coast.

Feature: Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: This is the place for ritual ceremonies, feto sau mane 'make adat'. The ritual building is an uma dato 'rumah adat', this is where ceremonial meetings are held and rituals are performed, and the sacred objects of the group are kept. (See also answer to 10.3). At 11:55 there is a story about the history of Tetun people. In the past, seven brothers from the kings clan Betun came from Atambua, one settled in Suai, one in Same, two in Atambua, two in Viqueque, one in Manatuto Suai Bada. This is why Tetun Terik is spoken in these places.

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Comment: The traditional rumah adat building may be referred to with data wahing, makai fukun (data = sacred, wahing = much; makai fukun is a parallel expression without meaning.)

Feature: Floor level of traditional houses?
Comment: Raised approx. 1 meter

Feature: Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Comment: The house is long, with two long slopes on the long sides, and two short slopes on the short sides. There is a door in the front, where the men enter, and a door at the right side, where the women enter. The men sit in the front end of the house. The kitchen is inside of the house, at the back end. This is the place for the women.

Feature: Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: patrilineal

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: Every moiety has its own leader. The leader is chosen by consensus among the adult men of the family. Age is important.

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: See answer to 6.6 and 6.7.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Comment: The wife of a ketua adat can represent him, e.g. when he died or is elsewhere. Otherwise, women cannot have leadership roles.

Feature: Are there men’s houses
Comment: Men and women can enter the rumah adat, but in the house, the men sit in the front and the women in the back.

Feature: Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: yes, hereditary   In Viqueque (desa Umain Kraik) there is a royal family, called Uhacae. They have been kings since the past till now.

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: yes, hereditary   There are slaves living in Selur. They have to serve the royal family. They are not allowed to do other work or live somewhere else.

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Comment: ema seluk, bai naka = foreigner. Lit. 'person else'

Feature: Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Is there a special name for this alliance?
Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: Name is taken from the father's family.

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Are there name taboos?
Comment: The name of an ancestor/parent can only be given when the person has died, not when he is still alive.

Feature: Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: Tetun Terik is not a locaility name.

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: ema seluk, bai naka = foreigner. Lit. 'person else'
